title: Backspace and delete buttons don't work properly for deleting tracks (lp:#1688074)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1688074) created by **Art (diametrix)**
```
Not so long ago a very useful feature was implemented which enables
deleting tracks while in the track drawing mode.  While in track drawing
mode you push delete to delete a track segment and backspace to delete the
whole track up to the nearest pad or via (there was a separate bug report
here https://bugs.launchpad.net/kicad/+bug/1490958)  Unfortunately it is
still not working properly.  If the track is within another footprint
extents or next to another footprint, pressing DEL or Backspace deletes the
track segment or the whole track (which is correct behavior) but at the
same time it deletes the footprint as well (which is not suppose to happen)
If you hit undo you can reverse deleting the footprint while the track
remains deleted.  So you can eventually get the the desired result, it just
takes several steps.

title: DRC ignores accidently deleted parts (lp:#1685516)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1685516) created by **Stephen (steejb)**
```
Most people run DRC prior to manufacture. I was alarmed to find a missing
footprint in the finished board.

I ran the DRC again - it passed...

I think I must have accidently deleted a footprint. Because upon re-
importing the netlist, the footprint appeared.

If the footprint exists in PcbNew, the DRC checks it against the netlist.
Thus, once I re-imported the netlist (no changes to the netlist since the
baord was manufactured, just a re-import), the offending footprint tripped
a DRC fail. This is correct.

However, if I (accidently) delete a footprint, the DRC passes.

So it seems the DRC corectly checks footprint pads for connectivity, but
ignores the total number of net nodes, and merrily passes a board which is
completely missing entire footprints - despite the netlist import.

description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1685508) created by **David Pearce (halzia)**
```

it is very easy to have a wire segment linkin two adjacent pins, but hard
to see superimposed on the sheet box outline.
I suggest that having a short external pin makes this much less likely as a
wire bridging the pins would be obvious.

title: Visibility control of 3D shapes in footprint (lp:#1685004)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1685004) created by **Art (diametrix)**
```
Footprint editor currently allows you select multiple 3D shapes for a
single footprint, which can be a very handy feature.  For example, it would
be convenient if I can have a single chip component footprint library for
capacitors, inductors and resistors and then add multiple 3D shapes for the
same footprint and then select for each component in PCBnew appropriate 3D
shape.  In the same manner if I have parts which differ in appearance but
share the same footprint you can add multiple shapes and then select
appropriate shape in PCBnew.  However, currently if you add multiple shapes
they all are showing simultaneously, which doesn't make sense.  Ether
selection needs to be restricted to a single shape per single footprint or
there needs to be a way to select between the shape for each component.
```

title: Mode to move *only* symbol or *only* netname etc (lp:#1680518)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1680518) created by **DiBosco (robert-wood)**
```
I should start by saying this is not a bug, but a feature request. I
believe this is the correct place to submit such things, so apologies if I
have misunderstood.

I should also say, that is is not something specific, to kicad, but
something that is lacking from all modern CAD systems.

I would like to see the ability to enter "modes" such as a move footprint
mode, delete net mode mode, mode reference designator mode, move by
reference designator mode etc etc.

It is, for example, incredible tiresome when shifting stuff on the screen
and you are constantly having to choose whether you want to delete, say, a
track, a component or a junction when they are all close together. It would
be much better to have the editor know that you want to delete tracks then
you could go round clicking knowing that you were only going to delete a
track and not worry about whether it was constantly asking you to clarify
whether you wanted to delete the junction or the symbol that was also in
the click vicinity.

So, in summary I am suggesting you have a menu and hotkey that would put
the editor into delete net mode and whenever you click on the screen, if
there is a net there it is immediately deleted. Importantly, do not exit
this mode once you have deleted a track until the escape key is pressed.

In the same way, you would have a mode where you selected move component
mode. Then, every time you clicked on the screen, it would just pick up
component under the the cursor, put it down when you next clicked and, very
importantly, still be in that same mode until you hit escape.

There are lots of other modes that would be equally as useful. For example
the mode you get when you hit T to move component. It should be the case
that once you place the component down, you should not have to press T
again to enter the next reference designator of the part or symbol you want
to move. It should just be there so you can immediately move the next part
by its ref des.

This kind of behaviour would *massively* cut down on keypresses and more
specifically mouse clicks. kicad and modern CAD systems in general are way
too clicky.
```

title: Footprint Position File output improvements needed (lp:#1679205)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1679205) created by **Art (diametrix)**
```
The x coordinates of the Position File need to be inverted for the bottom
layer.  Let's say that you picked the left corner for your position file as
the origin.  In PCB new the coordinates are of the same sign for the top
and the bottom layer because you are in the "see through" view.  However
when the board is flipped on the pick and place machine your top left
corner now became top right corner and all X coordinates now should be
negative.

And another suggestion.  For the ascii position file the separate fields
are delineated with spaces, so during file generation all the spaces in all
the fields used need to be replaced with underscore.  Not sure about other
fields, but I personally use spaces a lot in the value field (i.e.
designate voltage of a capacitor or precision, like 47uF 50V)  If those
spaces are not replaced the file will be corrupted when imported into a
pick and place machine.
```
Original tags: fabrication pcbnew

title: PCB editor rotates footprint around random center (lp:#1679190)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1679190) created by **Art (diametrix)**
```
Well not entirely random but pretty close.  When you need to rotate a
footprint you would make your selection and then use keyboard shortcut or
context menu to rotate the whole selection.  However, it seems that the
center of the rotation is defined by your mouse coordinates.  Considering
lack of capability to snap mouse pointer to grid this makes this
functionality completely unusable.  The only option to rotate a footprint
is to switch back to the default mode and do it there.  In the default mode
you select a rectangular area and the rotate around the center of that
rectangle, which is not the best solution but at least it is usable.  You
can select large grid size and make your rectangular selection symmetrical
around the origin, thus making sure that your selection is turned around
the origin.

Ultimately there should be an easy way to rotate selection either around
the origin or around the center of a pad.  You can have some logic
implemented to see if the mouse pointer is near the origin then the origin
is used as the center or if it is on a pad, then the center of the pad is
used.

The situation with the mirror function is even more confusing.  Mouse
pointer position does affect the position of the final result but it is not
immediately apparent as to how.  The same logic of mirroring it around an
axis or a center of a pad would be preferable.

title: Implement color themes (lp:#1678345)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1678345) created by **Jon Evans (craftyjon)**
```
Users should be able to switch between sets of color options (themes) in
all programs.  Ideally these themes should be stored as files that can be
shared / backed up / checked in to source control if desired.  Part of this
is a refactoring of the color settings code to be unified among all the
programs, and clean up some aspects of color handling when switching
between legacy and GAL canvases.  This will also enable a "reset to default
colors" option, in the form of a "KiCad Default" theme that cannot be
overwritten.
```

title: Default KISYS3DMOD path broken after extras installation (lp:#1677545)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1677545) created by **Jörg Hermann (joerg.hermann)**
```
KiCad 4.0.6 release, applies to nightly as well
Mac OS 10.9.5

After fresh KiCad install path configuration KISYS3DMOD points to
/Library/Application Support/kicad/modules/packages3d

Directory /Library/Application Support/kicad contains various subdirs,
notabely modules and packages3d. modules contains a README and a symlink
for packages3d pointing one directory upwards to the physical location of
the 3d packages - everything fine, all works.

Now user installs KiCad extras, with a modules directory full of footprints
but WITHOUT a packages3d symlink. By shoving the modules directory from dmg
to Applications Support/kicad/modules, the original modules directory is
overwritten. Although a warning pops up, the user accepts it, because he
WANTS to overwrite modules.
Now KISYS3DMOD points to a non existing symlink.

A novice user will then wonder, why he can't generate 3D views.

Suggested Fix: Have KISYS3DMOD point to /Library/Application
Support/kicad/packages3d right from the start, drop symlink in modules and
all is fine.

I don't know how this is implemented in other OS, I imagine similar
problems there.
```

title: FOOTPRINT_PREVIEW_PANEL may have locale issues (lp:#1676047)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1676047) created by **Chris Pavlina (pavlina-chris)**
```
FOOTPRINT_PREVIEW_PANEL's loader thread calls
FP_LIB_TABLE::FootprintLoadWithOptionalNickname. I'm not sure if this
function makes use of LOCALE_IO, but if so it does not belong in the
threaded environment. A possible and easy fix would be to wait until the
footprint selector has loaded all the footprints via its
FOOTPRINT_ASYNC_LOADER, since this is all handled there, before displaying
footprints. This fix would depend on cleaning up footprint caching, I think
(currently eeschema and pcbnew do not share a cache, and
FOOTPRINT_PREVIEW_PANEL runs in pcbnew's domain).

Filing this so I don't forget about it as I won't have time for kicad work
for a couple days.
```

title: Center of rotation isn't locked to grid (lp:#1674835)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1674835) created by **Felix Uhl (ifreilicht)**
```
I'm using pcbnew 4.0.4-stable on Windows 10.

Rotating a group with 'R' or with 'Ctrl'+'M' is not behaving like I expect.
I set the grid to 40mm to make absolutely sure that I know where it should
lock to.

Rotating with 'R' will rotate around the cursor, but not lock the cursor to
the grid, which means that all the components will end up in slightly off-
grid positions and are impossible to put back onto the grid.

Rotating with 'Ctrl'+'M' (Move Exactly) will rotate around the center of
the bounding box of my selected components, which is suboptimal if the
group of components should be around a point that is not the center of that
bounding box.
I'd rather it rotate around the cursor - locked to the grid - or to have an
option for me to set the center of rotation, also locked to the grid.

The current workaround for me is to draw a diagonal line at a 45° angle
through the group that should be rotated, and then select around that. This
makes the bounding box square around that line and thus allows me to rotate
precisely around the point I want to.
```

title: Wishlist: Unique zone "Clearance" for edge cuts (lp:#1662369)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1662369) created by **Evan Shultz (evan-shultz)**
```
I would like to have a unique clearance around zones to the board edge.
Currently, it appears the "Clearance" field applies to all copper elements
that the zone meets and the board edge.

For example, consider a zone on a high-voltage net. For 500V clearance, UL
60950 would require 1.6mm spacing and that is the value that I should put
into the Clearance field of the shape. I may want 1.6mm from this zone to
other copper, but if the product is in a plastic box with a single-sided
board it may be possible to run the zone right to the board edge. Pcbnew,
however, would still back off the board edge by 1.6mm which reduces my
usable routing area.

See the attached project for an example. The upper zone is priority 2 and
has 0.508mm clearance while the bottom zone is priority 1 and has 1.016mm
clearance. Both zones are backed off from the board edge by their clearance
value and the bottom zone, having a lower priority, backs off 1.016mm from
the upper zone. And also note that the net class for both zones' nets have
0.7mm spacing.

There are certainly hacks to get around this, but they're hacks. Since
board edge and copper-copper are, to me, distinct spacing requirements I
think they should be controlled separately.

I could be misusing Pcbnew or misunderstanding. If this can already be
handled, please forgive me and point me in the right direction. Thank you.

title: Grid dots too small on high DPI displays (Eeschema) (lp:#1660560)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1660560) created by **Robert Nicoll (virtual81)**
```
When using Eeschema on a Notebook PC a 14" 1440p (QHD) display the dots
that make up the grid are unable to be seen with the naked eye at ordinary
sitting distance.
When peering up close to the screen the green dots are visible.

Solutions could be to increase dot size, or make dots black, thus using all
3 (RGB) sub pixels.

Also mentioned in the forum by davidsrsb...
"High DPI displays are also the root cause of the hard to see unrouted
connection lines in OpenGL canvas.
This will be an increasing problem as pixel size continues to shrink"

I'm new to KiCad thus am not familiar with this issue, but suspect it too
to be relevant, and suspect i may come across it when the time comes.

title: Make it more obvious that you can type units into many textCtrls (lp:#1660156)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1660156) created by **Chris Pavlina (pavlina-chris)**
```
Many text fields in pcbnew allow the user to type a unit - for example [1].
The interface does nothing to make this clear, however. We should come up
with a way to make clear to the user that the unit is available for
editing.

Proposal: instead of having the unit outside the field, put it *in* the
unit, and autoselect just the number when the dialog is opened. If the user
accidentally deletes the unit from the field, default to the currently
selected unit as we already do.

Reference: https://bugs.launchpad.net/kicad/+bug/1660150

[1] https://misc.c4757p.com/unit-in-field.png
```

title: pcbnew: positioning of components in relation to already positioned ones (lp:#1660154)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1660154) created by **Adam (arudzins)**
```
It is possible "manually", thanks to the ability to set a zero for relative
position. But is a "manual labor", it can require to change the grid, if a
component is off the current grid. For larger boards this can be really
cumbersome.

I suggest to add an option similar to "move exactly", the name could be
like "place exactly relative to".

Also, it would be great to have in the context menu options to copy x or y
coordinate of another component (not necessarily, or rather: not only a
footprint), to facilitate positioning components in line.
```

title: pcbnew: selection of size for tracks and vias (lp:#1660150)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1660150) created by **Adam (arudzins)**
```
Somehow it is just the way, that it is convenient to use millimeters for
defining vias and mills (or inches) for defining tracks. It is common to
use a few different sizes for both.

The only reasonable way of changing their size I know is to press Q in
OpenGL mode while routing. It would be great, but it requires to cycle
through units all the time.

I suggest to make the units in that size selection dialog independent of
the units selected for the main view (which are useful for measuring,
placement etc., and generally are defined once for a design, or perhaps
even for a designer).

I think that the simplest and the best solution is to provide two text
inputs for each size in the dialog, one for input in inches (or mills) and
the second for input in millimetres (when the user inputs a value into one
of them, the value in the second one gets updated accordingly).

Alternatively, this dialog could contain two dropdowns, one for selection
of units for tracks and the another for vias.
```

title: pcbnew: margin for subtraction of soldermask from silkscreen (lp:#1660148)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1660148) created by **Adam (arudzins)**
```
This option is included for generation of gerbers and that's where it
should be. But the silkscreen is removed only from the soldermask openings,
while a bigger margin may be required. This additional margin could be
configured in the same dialog or, preferably, it could be defined per-pad
basis, just as we can configure a custom soldermask opening per pad. So my
recommendation is to add a "silk to soldermask clearance" property for
pads.

Currently, the not so convenient "volatile" workaround is:
- generate all gerbers,
- save the design, preferably not forgetting to make a backup,
- redefine soldermask openings of all pads in question (not forgetting
about any of them),
- generate silkscreen gerbers with silk-soldermask subtraction,
- do not save the design in the above two steps!
- recover the saved design.
```

title: Warn about single pad nets in Eeschema (lp:#1660120)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1660120) created by **Adam (arudzins)**
```
KiCAD has no usable mechanism for warning the user against single pad nets.

For example, if I made a mistake in the schematics and swapped two letters
in a label, it is likely that I would found this out when the manufactured
PCB doesn't work as it was supposed to.

During netlist import pcbnew informs about deleting single pad nets, but
for a large PCB (where the problem is likely), if you even know this,
this is easy to overlook, inconvenient and thus unreliable..

Right now I use an external program to parse the netlist and check
for single pad nets.

Probably the easiest solution would be to have eeschema open a window
displaying the labels of all the single pad nets with a label. To be
less annoying, this window could have a checkbox not to be displayed again
for this schematics. In the netlist generation dialog there could also be
an associated checkbox telling to show this warning.
```

title: Different design rules for different areas of the board. (lp:#1654571)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1654571) created by **Ondrej Ille (illeondrej)**
```
Hi,

I was recently routing complex CPU board with DDR3. Routing out DDR3
signals under the BGA
and out of the BGA requires different minimal distances between the tracks.
It would
be really good to have zone DRC feature which would allow override default
DRC rules by
zone specific ones for either all signals or some signal groups.

A very close issue to this issue is that once the signals are routed with
e.g. 0.1 mm
distance, then DRC minimal value is changed to e.g. 0.3 mm, it is
impossible to route
the signals further (the actual ending distance must be increased manually
and route only then).
Also if two signals corrupt DRC minimal distance at any previous point the
Shove tool
does not work on further segments of these signals.

Ondrej Ille
```

title: DRC ignores traces crossing edgecut (lp:#1648055)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1648055) created by **Frank Severinsen (shack)**
```
Dear Kicad Developers

I found an issue with the DRC which I think would be worth looking into.
It seems the DRC doesnt check for traces crossing the edgecut.

Currently, the P&S router will happily push a trace out of the edgecut when
using the shove mode. (I am also making bug report on this)
for this reason the traces might go out of the outline without the user
even noticing it.
I would suppose simply treating the edge cut as any other trace would give
a DRC error when crossing the edgecut.
but perhaps having a seperate clearence to edgecut could be nicer since it
would allow the traces to go closer.

Though this is pretty easy to inspect manually, I believe the DRC should
provide the best possible chance for a functioning board.

tested on 4.0.4 and newest nightly

Greetings Frank Severinsen
```

title: I and U selection shortcuts work on hover track even when another is selected (lp:#1645670)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1645670) created by **Matthijs Kooijman (matthijskooijman)**
```
After using the interactive router / OpenGL view in pcbnew for a while, I
figured out that the "I" and "U" shortcuts ("copper connection" and
"trivial connection") work on the track the mouse is currently hovering
above.

Initially, I had assumed that these shortcuts worked on the currently
selected track. I found that the shortcuts behaved erratically, though,
sometimes they worked and sometimes they would not. Now I realize that this
depended on whether I had moved the mouse after selecting the track.
Looking back, I think my assumption came from the fact that other tools do
work on the selected element.

I would suggest extending these shortcuts so they also work with the
currently selected track. Now that I know about the hovering behavior, that
is easy to work with, but I think that working from the selected track
might also be useful (not in the least to prevent confusion with a new user
as I have found). I think there's two alternatives here:

 1. Whenever a track is selected, use it, even when the mouse hovers over
another track.
 2. Only when the track is not hovering over a track, use the selected
track (if any).

I think #1 would make the most sense, mostly to be consistent with other
shortcuts (I just tried E - edit, F - flip, ^D - duplicate, which all work
on hover only when no element is selected).

I have been using the 4.0.4 release, and also yesterday's version from the
4.0 branch for this.
```

3. Import resulting DXF file to pcbnew

[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1632048) created by **Jan Krieger (jkriege2)**
```
Take any component, e.g. TEST from device.lib. It's definition in the file
looks like this:

#
# TEST
#
DEF TEST P 0 40 N N 1 F N
F0 "TP" 0 300 50 H V C BNN
F1 "TEST" 0 250 50 H V C CNN
F2 "" 0 0 50 H V C CNN
F3 "" 0 0 50 H V C CNN
DRAW
P 6 0 1 0 0 200 -50 150 0 100 50 150 0 200 0 200 N
X ~ 1 0 0 100 U 50 50 1 1 P
ENDDRAW
ENDDEF

and then hide its VALUE-field and save the lib in the symbol editr. The
component becomes:

#
# TEST
#
DEF ~TEST TP 0 40 N N 1 F N
F0 "TP" 0 300 50 H V C BNN
F1 "TEST" 0 250 50 H I C CNN
F2 "" 0 0 50 H V C CNN
F3 "" 0 0 50 H V C CNN
DRAW
P 6 0 1 0 0 200 -50 150 0 100 50 150 0 200 0 200 N
X ~ 1 0 0 100 U 50 50 1 1 P
ENDDRAW
ENDDEF

Note that now we have "DEF ~TEST" instead of "DEF TEST" before.

Best,
JAN
```

title: Simulator freezes until return is pressed in terminal (lp:#1630676)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1630676) created by **Jonatan Liljedahl (kymatica)**
```
Most often (but sometimes not), running the simulator freezes the app,
until one switches to the terminal where kicad was started[1] and press the
return key a number of times, then the simulation completes. There's no
errors or Y/n questions in the simulator log or in the terminal.

[1] - At least on OSX, kicad must be started from the terminal with proper
environment variable set to make it find the needed ngspice init file and
codemodels.
```
Original tags: cern eeschema ngspice

title: Initialization of ngspice on OSX (lp:#1630675)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1630675) created by **Jonatan Liljedahl (kymatica)**
```
On OSX, the installed bundle does not include the necessary codemodels and
init files for ngspice, so even though libngspice is bundled, one must also
install ngspice separately. This might be OK in itself, but the problem is
that kicad (or the bundled libngspice?) does not know where ngspice is
installed, so it does not find the needed files. A workaround is to start
kicad from the terminal and set an environment variable like this:

$ export SPICE_LIB_DIR=/Applications/ngspice/share/ngspice/
$ /Applications/Kicad/kicad.app/Contents/MacOS/kicad

This is not very user friendly.. ;)
```

description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1629330) created by **xzcvczx (xzcvczx)**
```
The following functions/type have been deprecated since 10.9, as this was
released ~3yrs ago there is no guarantee of how much longer apple will keep
these functions around

common/gal/opengl/opengl_gal.cpp
    gluNewTess()
    gluTessProperty()
    gluDeleteTess()
    gluTessBeginPolygon()
    gluTessBeginContour()
    gluTessVertex()
    gluTessEndContour()
    gluTessEndPolygon()
    gluTessCallback()

utils/idftools/vrml_layer
    gluNewTess()
    gluTessCallback()
    gluTessProperty()
    gluTessNormal()
    gluDeleteTess()
    gluTessBeginPolygon()
    gluTessEndPolygon()
    gluTessBeginContour()
    gluTessEndContour()
    gluTessVertex()
    gluErrorString()

3d-viewer/3d_rendering/3d_render_ogl_legacy/ogl_legacy_utils.cpp
    GLUquadricObj
    gluNewQuadric()
    gluQuadricDrawStyle()
    gluQuadricNormals()
    gluCylinder()
    gluDeleteQuadric()
    gluDisk()
    gluSphere()



For the following 2 the recommended replacement from the deprecation notice
is GLXMatrix4MakePerspective (but that would require a later version of
opengl) It can also be replaced by
glm::perspective(http://stackoverflow.com/a/19647181) which wouldn't
require a later version of ogl

3d-viewer/3d_rendering/3d_render_ogl_legacy/c3d_render_ogl_legacy.cpp
    gluPerspective()
3d-viewer/3d_model_viewer/c3d_model_viewer.cpp
    gluPerspective()

```

ANDed instead of ORed. I.e. an item is displayed on a certain layer only if
both this layer is enabled in "Layer" tab and this item type is enabled in

reference.

making-a-footprint-array/
